https://www.ft.com...-b592-5fe435b57a3b

Glencore has announced a “long-term” deal to supply cobalt to Belgium’s Umicore, Europe’s largest producer of battery materials for the electric car industry.

The cobalt will be sourced from Glencore’s two large copper and cobalt mines in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which do not involve any form of child labour, Umicore said.

The agreement “guarantees Umicore’s security of supply for a substantial part of its longer-term cobalt needs for its expanding global battery materials value chain,” it said.

The deal comes following Umicore’s agreement last week to purchase the Kokkola cobalt refinery from US copper miner Freeport-McMoran for $150m, giving it control over Europe’s largest refinery for the metal.

A take-or-pay contract for ~15% of NMC capacity but at what price?
Umicore has announced that it has signed a multi-year non-exclusive take-or-pay NMC supply agreement with LG Chemical. Under the agreement Umicore will supply a total of 125,000t of NMC cathodes over several years to LG Chemical in Poland, South Korea and China. The vast majority of the supply will come from Umicore's NMC plant in Poland, which is expected to be commissioned in 2H20 and has planned capacity of ~40ktpa. We assume the duration of contract is 5 years (~25ktpa), which represents ~15% of Umicore's total NMC capacity by 2022 (~160ktpa of NMC & ~15ktpa of LCO). In our opinion it is hard to quantify how positive this is for Umicore without knowing the structure of the contracts (pricing & margins) relative to the current EV Rechargeable Battery Materials business

Yesterday, Umicore's CEO, Marc Grynberg, and CFO, Filip Platteeuw hosted a sell side lunch where most of the discussion centred around the evolving cathode landscape. What is clear is that the cathode market conditions as it relates to pricing and competition have deteriorated versus a year ago. This, combined with the limited market visibility, and a sense that cathode producers are largely considered a tier 2 auto supplier, leaves the risk to both valuation and FY'20 estimates skewed to the downside. Umicore, the triple EV play, cathodes, anodes and battery recycling: Another noteworthy point is
the indication that UMI and LG Chem are exploring a possible battery recycling cooperation. UMI has
a small battery recycling pilot plant on the site of its principal PM refinery in Hoboken Belgium and in
2012 first long term lithium battery recycling contracts for UMI were announced by Toyota, Nissan and
Tesla Europe followed up last year by Audi and BMW. There are two possibilities for end of life EV
batteries - reuse in stationary energy storage applications or metal recovery and we believe a growing
proportion of car makers and battery makers are coming to favour the recycling route because it
provides an additional source of overground supply for battery grade cobalt and nickel. EV Battery
recycling is unlikely to be a meaningful future revenue stream for UMI before 2025 but could be an
important longer tem contributor. Likewise UMI may have some additional EV battery opportunities in
high capacity silicon doped anodes although initially this is likely to be tested in shorter life, smaller
format batteries for portable electronic applications.
